U can copy cudnn.h and its lib into corresponding cuda path, i.e. cuda/include, cuda/lib64.
check make/config.mk
It depends on the behalf of your operators. [memonger](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-memonger) is an extension of MxNet with some extra time cost if you can tolerate.

@Godricly  Thank you ! I sovled this issue just now 

step1 : 
(download cudnn first,then extract)

cd cuda  (the extract cudnn path,not the cuda path )

sudo cp lib64/\* /usr/local/cuda/lib64/
sudo cp include/cudnn.h /usr/local/cuda/include/

step 2: 
just set USE_CUDNN=1 in  config.mk file .

step 3:
make

It is no need to set USE_CUDNN_PATH right now .
I think this should be helpful for someone else.
hostfile should be like the form ip:port

```
Encoder: bidirectional LSTM
Decoder: LSTM
LSTM hidden: 512
embedding size: 512

target_vocab_size = 50000
unroll_length: 350
batch_size = 64
```

Any idea to reduce the memory cost?
Thanks.

Hi @qcl6355 

The example you contributed help me learned a lot about the framework and api. I'm now wondering whether there's any possible to use more high-level api, which just simply define layers and avoid explicitly figuring out network's size.

Another question is, I notice the code doesn't support multichannel setting as the original paper did, in which it only updates one of the two channels.
This may be helpful. [CTC input node is not complete](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2217) @xlvector       I met the same problem.

I have read through nccl code before, there are two factors
- Allreduce reduction using ring based approach: this forms each device in a ring, and do ring based passing until the data get collected.
  - The ring based approach kinda of partitions  the data in an array equally, so likely each peer in the ring have balanced work load.
- Directly memory access to other GPU: When doing addition, no copy buffer is allocated, but memory is directly accessed from other GPU, this is possible when unified memory access is enabled.

# Break it Down

## Partition Strategy

How do we partition the workload in the parameters. 
- The most balanced way is to partition the array equally for big arrays(what we do now)
- For conv weights, partition by parameters seems to be enough.
  - Have advantage of concurrent scheduling(overlap copy with communication)
  - Can be a bit imbalanced in workload for large arrays

## Reduction Strategy

There are several strategies for all reduce, assume there is K devices, and N parameters to pass
- All to all: copy all data to one device and aggregate, choose different reduction point per partition
  - The communication is equally divided among the channels between peers
- Ring based reduction, form a ring, and pass data around the ring.
  - Communication is bottlenecked by the minimum peer to peer bandwidth between neighbors in the ring.
    - i.e. if there is hierarchical PCI-e structure, this may not be optimal
- Tree shape reduction
  - Could be useful when the communication structure is like a tree

## Direct Memory Access

With unified memory access, there is no need to allocate copy buffer, but kernels seems can directly access memory in another device instead

# What we can do

Here are the things we can do, besides adopting nccl. 
- Support direct memory access for reduction kernels in our case, this should eliminate the extra copy buffer, thus solves the memory problem
- We can revisit the items here later, since nccl is still somewhat synchronized, my guess is async scheduling and some perf tuning on different communication strategy might still help.
Yes, but inplace will only be done if its source has not been used by another operator
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2942

Okay, yes, the method described in #1658 does look useful. If I understand properly, it does have the limitation that the number of possible classes in the network will be the same for each label. If the actual number of classes for each label varies, I think it should still work; it will simply never learn to predict any of the unused class indexes for each label. However, it seems like it could be inefficient if, for example, the data had a large number of binary labels and then a few labels with up to 1000 possible classes.

@freddycct Thanks for the explanation! I see the problem now! Because the embedding layer picks some arbitrary non-zero outputs for the PAD symbol, making the forwarded state of the RNN different from an initial zero-state.
@novog, agreed. Thanks for the comment.
@pluskid thank you for noticing! i hope we solve this soon!

Yes, it is a little bit trickier than I first thought. Not only the bottom embedding layer, but every upper layers that produces forward states needs to know when a frame is a padding frame, so that the forwarded state could be zero-ed. I think one solution is to pass a sequence of 0-1 masks (0 being a pad frame, and 1 being a normal frame), and let all the forward states to be multiplied (with broadcasting) by those masks.

Mask is a good idea. But I think special initialized embedding matrix is
also enough for encoder begin padding and decoder end padding.

As a temporary fix, add MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE=NaiveEngine to your environment variables.
But you need to be very careful not to do any synchronization in CustomOp. i.e. don't use asnumpy() in custom op.

You can use simple_bind() and some manual code to initialize the weights and fill in your input variables. Read this tutorial https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/5ff545f2345f9b607b81546a168665bd63d02d9f/example/notebooks/simple_bind.ipynb
particularly the "in [5]" line and use some code like this to input your multiple inputs:

executor = eg.simple_bind(ctx=ctx, data = data_shape, grad_req = 'write')
arg_arrays = executor.arg_arrays
grad_arrays = executor.grad_arrays
aux_arrays = executor.aux_arrays
args = dict(zip(eg.list_arguments(),arg_arrays))
grads = dict(zip(eg.list_arguments(),grad_arrays))
aux_states = dict(zip(eg.list_auxiliary_states(),aux_arrays))

input1 = mx.nd.ones(data_shape)   # or read something from your data
input2 = mx.nd.ones(data_shape) 
args["src_input"][:] = input1
args["tar_input"][:] = input2
To answer the question, mxnet indeed share memory between forward and backward pass
One comment, this PR seems still contains additional code that has nothing todo with RPN, e.g. load from bytes, which should be deleted

When the gradient is calculated, it is different than the normal softmax gradient, so I don't see how. Please help.

On page 19 of the reinforcement learning course, Instead of multiplying the difference/delta/"score function" by results earlier in the chain, it is multiplied by the eventual rewards that might be sampled. The cost function is also based on these rewards.

While I hoped to use standard loss and gradients, this uses a log-likelihood trick to optimize over two things at once.

PAGE 19:
http://www0.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/D.Silver/web/Teaching_files/pg.pdf

- Documentation (most important)
- Some kind of graph creation debugging tool

- dynamic execution capability for Operators (for example, stochastic depth and fractal network )

thanks for your reply, @kxf8608 
i use this code in R and meet new trouble.

my dataset is a matrix. each row is a sample and each column is a feature.
so I think the "data_shape" is the dim of the dataset. (for example, c(500, 6000))

> data_shape = c(500,6000)
> executor = mx.simple.bind(eg, data = data_shape,grad_req = "write")
> **Error: not compatible with requested type**
> executor = mx.simple.bind(eg, data = data_shape,grad_req = "null")
> **Error: not compatible with requested type**

I know very little about python. Is there any difference between the param grad_req's value of R and python?

data_shape should be the batch data's dimension. For example, (64,3,256,128) means a batch of 64 3-channel images (RGB) with spatial dimension of 256 height and 128 width. For fully connected layer, it only accepts (batch, length) data.

grad_req should be 'write' most of the time. If you set it as NULL the model will not learn.

About your question, sorry about my previous reply and I did not find the actual solution. I suggest 1) use single input and then a mxnet.symbol.SliceChannel layer to cut it into two pieces. Alternatively, 2) use bind() rather than simple_bind(). See http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/symbol_in_pictures.html#bind-and-execute-symbol

Here are some thoughts about the docs:
- [ ] A summary page of all the examples
- [ ] A summary page of new features recently added. Each time a new feature is added, simple explanation and sample codes must be provided.
- WE CANNOT SAY "YOU CAN JUST USE XXX" to users, but there is no doc or simple examples for XXX. Each time we mention that, a doc or example must be provided.
- [ ] A step by step tutorial to teach beginners how to implement some basic operations in NN, such as finetune, extract features, etc. These could cover more than 80% usage
- [ ] Finish CS231n homework and projects with Minpy and MXNet

I must `sudo` for make and make test to prevent some permission issues.

```
[zihao.zzh@gpu1031.et2 /home/zihao.zzh/packages/mxnet]
$sudo make scalatest
(cd /home/zihao.zzh/packages/mxnet/scala-package; \
    mvn verify -Plinux-x86_64-gpu -Dcxx="g++" \
        -Dcflags="-DMSHADOW_FORCE_STREAM -Wall -O3 -I/home/zihao.zzh/packages/mxnet/mshadow/ -I/home/zihao.zzh/packages/mxnet/dmlc-core/include -fPIC -Iinclude -msse3 -funroll-loops -Wno-unused-parameter -Wno-unknown-pragmas -I/usr/local/cuda-7.5/include -DMSHADOW_USE_CBLAS=1 -DMSHADOW_USE_MKL=0 -DMSHADOW_RABIT_PS=0 -DMSHADOW_DIST_PS=0 -DMSDHADOW_USE_PASCAL=0 -DMXNET_USE_OPENCV=1 `pkg-config --cflags opencv` -fopenmp -DMSHADOW_USE_CUDNN=1  -DMXNET_USE_NVRTC=0" -Dldflags="-pthread -lm -lcudart -lcublas -lcurand -L/usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib64 -L/usr/local/cuda-7.5/lib -lopenblas -fopenmp -lrt `pkg-config --libs opencv` -lcudnn  -lcuda" \
        -Dlddeps="/home/zihao.zzh/packages/mxnet/dmlc-core/libdmlc.a" )
```

This is solved by add:
ADD_CFLAGS = -D_MWAITXINTRIN_H_INCLUDED -D__STRICT_ANSI__
in config.mk

hi, @piiswrong , I also meet the same issue. I trained the model use the newest version of the code, and also used the same version of the code to predict. The result seemed totally wrong. If I set gamma to 1.0, I can get the right result. I have to reset the gamma to 1.0 manually to use the model.
I changed the source, I add a function to set the GPU that i want use. So this problem has been solved.

@leoxiaobin This is a known issue due to some legacy reasons. Setting gamma to 1.0 is the correct fix.
